overview: From 2025-10-26 to 2025-11-02, ethereum-optimism/specs had 20 new PRs (14 merged), 0 new issues, and 41 active contributors.

topPRs.title: docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create FaultDisputeGame specification
topPRs.author: devin-ai-integration
topPRs.body:
# Create comprehensive FaultDisputeGame specification covering all variants

## Summary

Created a new contract specification for the FaultDisputeGame family at `specs/experimental/contracts/dispute/fault-dispute-game.md`. This specification covers five contract variants that share the core bisection-based dispute resolution mechanism but differ in access control and architectural implementation:

- **FaultDisputeGame**: Base permissionless V1 implementation
- **PermissionedDisputeGame**: Permissioned V1 with proposer/challenger roles
- **SuperPermissionedDisputeGame**: Permissioned variant extending SuperFaultDisputeGame
- **FaultDisputeGameV2**: Permissionless V2 using Immutable Args Pattern
- **PermissionedDisputeGameV2**: Permissioned V2 with Immutable Args Pattern

The specification includes:
- Overview and Contract Variants sections explaining the family
- 9 Definitions (including Proposer Role, Challenger Role, Immutable Args Pattern)
- 3 Assumptions about external dependencies (AnchorStateRegistry, VM, DelayedWETH)
- 7 Invariants including new i01-007 for permissioned access control
- Complete function specifications for 30+ public/external functions

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

- [ ] **Verify multi-variant approach**: Confirm that documenting all 5 variants in a single specification (rather than separate specs) aligns with documentation standards and makes sense for maintainability
- [ ] **Cross-check permission model**: Review invariant i01-007 and the permission-related updates to `initialize()`, `step()`, and `move()` functions against actual contract code to ensure accuracy, especially the distinction between which variants have which restrictions
- [ ] **Validate V2 architectural changes**: Check that the Immutable Args Pattern definition and V2-specific behaviors (especially in `initialize()` with variable calldata length) accurately reflect the architectural refactoring
- [ ] **Review invariants for completeness**: Verify that the 7 invariants capture all critical cross-function security properties, particularly around game resolution, bond distribution, and access control
- [ ] **Spot-check function behaviors**: Select 3-5 critical functions (e.g., `resolveClaim`, `closeGame`, `challengeRootL2Block`) and verify their MUST/MUST NOT requirements match actual contract implementation

### Notes

This specification was created entirely from code analysis without ability to test against actual deployments. The spec attempts to be comprehensive but may have missed subtle edge cases or variant-specific behaviors that aren't immediately obvious from code reading alone. Pay particular attention to areas where behavior differs between variants (especially V1 vs V2 and permissioned vs permissionless).

**Session**: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/5f4083160bbf44b5bf07eb21550b9af7  
**Requested by**: Ariel Diaz (ariel@oplabs.co) / @aliersh

topPRs.title: docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create L1StandardBridge specification
topPRs.author: devin-ai-integration
topPRs.body:
# docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create L1StandardBridge specification

## Summary

Created a comprehensive specification for the L1StandardBridge contract following the canonical OP Stack specification format. This spec documents the L1 side of the standard bridge system that enables ETH and ERC20 token transfers between Ethereum L1 and OP Stack L2 chains.

**Key sections:**
- **Overview**: High-level description of the bridge's role in escrow and token handling
- **Definitions**: OptimismMintableERC20 and Native L1 Token concepts
- **Assumptions**: 4 trust assumptions about L2StandardBridge, L1CrossDomainMessenger, SystemConfig/SuperchainConfig, and token implementations
- **Invariants**: 3 critical security properties (deposit liveness, withdrawal liveness, one-to-one custody)
- **Function Specification**: Complete documentation of all 19 public/external functions (excluding version())

This spec mirrors the structure and patterns established in the existing L2StandardBridge specification.

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

- [ ] **Verify invariants are accurate**: Review the 3 invariants (i01-001 through i01-003) against the actual L1StandardBridge.sol contract code to ensure they correctly capture the critical security properties. Pay special attention to the one-to-one custody invariant.
- [ ] **Check assumptions completeness**: Verify the 4 assumptions cover all external dependencies. Consider whether additional assumptions are needed around unsupported token types (transfer fees, rebasing, blocklists mentioned in contract comments).
- [ ] **Spot-check function specifications**: Pick 3-5 functions (especially finalize functions and initialization) and verify the MUST/MUST NOT statements match the actual implementation, including revert conditions and event emissions.
- [ ] **Verify L1/L2 terminology**: Scan through the spec to ensure "L1" and "L2" are used correctly throughout (easy to mix up when using L2StandardBridge as template).

### Test Plan
Since this is documentation only:
1. Read through the spec alongside the L1StandardBridge.sol contract
2. Verify the spec would be sufficient for someone to implement the contract from scratch
3. Check that the spec is consistent with the existing L2StandardBridge spec (they should be mirrors with L1/L2 swapped)

### Notes
- Pattern followed: Used existing L2StandardBridge spec as template for structure and format
- All markdown linting checks passed (TOC generation, markdown format, spelling, filenames)
- No code changes - documentation only
- Link to Devin run: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/8d4a6a3943514dfdb21ea27c059d9482
- Requested by: Ariel Diaz (ariel@oplabs.co) / @aliersh

topPRs.title: docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create PreimageOracle specification
topPRs.author: devin-ai-integration
topPRs.body:
# docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create PreimageOracle specification

## Summary

Created a comprehensive specification for the PreimageOracle contract, which provides data availability for fault proof execution. The spec covers:

- **Standard preimage routes**: local data, keccak256, sha256, blob (with KZG proofs), and precompile results
- **Large Preimage Proposal (LPP) system**: For preimages too large to submit in a single transaction, including incremental merkleization with keccak256 state commitments, challenge mechanism, and bond-based security
- **5 invariants**: Data integrity, proposal finality, challenge correctness, bond conservation, and local data isolation
- **2 assumptions**: Challenger monitoring and sufficient gas for precompile calls
- **16 function specifications**: All public/external functions except `version()`

Added 3 new words to the dictionary: `merkleization`, `incentivizes`, `returndatasize`.

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

This is a **yellow risk** PR (new specification from scratch). Please verify:

- [ ] **Invariants are truly cross-function properties**: Review each of the 5 invariants (i01-001 through i01-005) to ensure they describe system-wide properties that span multiple functions, not single-function behaviors. Pay special attention to i01-005 (Local Data Isolation) - verify it's genuinely cross-function.

- [ ] **Large Preimage Proposal flow is accurately specified**: The LPP system is the most complex part. Verify the sequence `initLPP → addLeavesLPP → (optional challenge) → squeezeLPP` is correctly described, especially:
  - Merkle tree construction and verification requirements
  - State commitment validation in challenge functions
  - Conditions for successful challenges vs. successful squeeze

- [ ] **Function specifications match contract behavior**: Cross-reference key functions against the actual contract code, especially:
  - `loadBlobPreimagePart` - KZG proof verification flow
  - `addLeavesLPP` - Merkle tree updates and preimage part extraction
  - `challengeLPP` / `challengeFirstLPP` / `squeezeLPP` - State matrix validation logic

### Test Plan

1. Review the spec against the contract source: `packages/contracts-bedrock/src/cannon/PreimageOracle.sol`
2. Verify all public/external functions are documented (except `version()`)
3. Check that assumptions a01-001 and a01-002 accurately reflect external dependencies
4. Confirm invariant severity ratings align with actual security impact
5. Validate that function specifications provide sufficient detail for implementation

### Notes

- All linting checks passed (markdown, TOC, spelling)
- No Dependencies section included (as it's deprecated per guidelines)
- Session: [Devin run](https://app.devin.ai/sessions/ae338f6f7a0846ba82a3e3aaa5ce8f86)
- Requested by: Ariel Diaz (@aliersh)

topPRs.title: docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create GovernanceToken specification
topPRs.author: devin-ai-integration
topPRs.body:
# docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create GovernanceToken specification

## Summary

Created a comprehensive specification for the GovernanceToken contract following the canonical format. The spec documents the ERC20 governance token with voting/delegation capabilities (ERC20Votes) and controlled minting through the MintManager owner. Key sections include:

- **Overview**: High-level description of the token's role in OP Stack governance
- **Assumptions**: Owner governance constraints and ERC20Votes supply limits
- **Invariants**: 3 invariants covering voting power accuracy, transfer freedom, and minting authorization
- **Function Specification**: Complete documentation of all public/external functions including mint, burn/burnFrom, delegation (delegate, delegateBySig), voting queries (getVotes, getPastVotes, etc.), and standard ERC20/ERC20Permit functions

The spec is based on the actual contract implementation at `packages/contracts-bedrock/src/governance/GovernanceToken.sol`, which is a straightforward composition of OpenZeppelin contracts (ERC20Burnable, ERC20Votes, Ownable) with a custom owner-only mint function.

**Note**: An experimental spec existed at `/specs/experimental/gov-token.md` describing GovernanceDelegation integration, but this was NOT implemented in the actual contract, so I based this spec on the simpler `/specs/governance/gov-token.md` and the actual contract code.

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

- [ ] **Verify inherited function behaviors are accurate**: The spec documents behavior from OpenZeppelin's ERC20Votes, ERC20Permit, and ERC20Burnable. Spot-check that documented behaviors (especially voting power updates, delegation mechanics, and signature validation) match the actual OpenZeppelin implementations used by the contract.

- [ ] **Review invariant classification**: Particularly iGT-003 ("Unauthorized minting is impossible") - confirm this is appropriate as an invariant rather than just being in the mint() function spec. The guidelines allow critical security properties in either location, but worth double-checking.

- [ ] **Validate assumptions are true external dependencies**: Especially aGT-002 about the ERC20Votes total supply constraint - is this really an "assumption" (external dependency) or just a technical limitation of the inherited implementation?

- [ ] **Confirm no experimental features were included**: The experimental spec at `/specs/experimental/gov-token.md` describes GovernanceDelegation hook integration that doesn't exist in the actual contract. Verify this spec correctly documents only what's actually implemented.

### Notes

- All lint checks passed (markdown, TOC, spelling, filenames)
- Excluded `version()` function from spec as per guidelines (standard ISemver)
- Used N/A for Definitions since all terms are standard ERC20/voting concepts
- Placed spec at `/specs/experimental/contracts/governance/governance-token.md` following the path mapping rules

**Session**: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/85e0ab1d881c4a94b1ee4d43614b20f3  
**Requested by**: Ariel Diaz (ariel@oplabs.co), GitHub: @aliersh

topPRs.title: docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create L2StandardBridge specification
topPRs.author: devin-ai-integration
topPRs.body:
# docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create L2StandardBridge specification

## Summary

This PR adds a comprehensive specification for the L2StandardBridge contract, which enables ETH and ERC20 token transfers between L1 and L2. The specification follows the canonical format used for other bridge contracts in the experimental/contracts directory.

**Key components:**
- **Overview**: High-level description of the bridge's role
- **Definitions**: OptimismMintableERC20 and Native L2 Token concepts
- **Assumptions**: Three trust assumptions (L1StandardBridge, L2CrossDomainMessenger, token implementations)
- **Invariants**: Three critical security properties focused on liveness and custody
  - Users receive assets on L2 when depositing from L1
  - Users can claim assets on L1 when withdrawing from L2
  - One-to-one custody across chains (no double-minting or draining)
- **Function Specification**: Complete documentation of all 14 public/external functions (excluding version())

The spec documents the intended behavior based on the StandardBridge.sol parent contract and L2StandardBridge.sol implementation.

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

- [ ] **Verify invariants accurately reflect security properties**: Check that the three invariants (cross-chain liveness and 1:1 custody) are the most critical properties for this bridge contract and appropriately span multiple functions
- [ ] **Cross-reference function specifications with actual contract code**: Spot-check 3-5 functions (especially finalizeBridgeETH, finalizeBridgeERC20, and withdraw) to ensure the MUST/MUST NOT statements match the actual Solidity implementation
- [ ] **Validate assumptions are true dependencies**: Confirm that the three assumptions (trusted L1StandardBridge, trusted L2CrossDomainMessenger, correct token implementation) are actually required for the contract to function correctly

### Notes

- All linting checks passed (markdown formatting, TOC generation, spelling)
- The specification format matches the existing L2ERC721Bridge spec for consistency
- Legacy functions (withdraw, withdrawTo, MESSENGER, OTHER_BRIDGE) are included for completeness
- The spec intentionally excludes the `version()` function per guidelines

**Session**: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/def7608367e94759b17419372a3d08dd  
**Requested by**: Ariel Diaz (ariel@oplabs.co) / @aliersh
